newsitem.title: LEBANON: BEIRUT BOURSE SLIPS AS INVESTORS STAY CLEAR.
newsitem.headline: BEIRUT BOURSE SLIPS AS INVESTORS STAY CLEAR.

text.p: The Beirut Stock Exchange struggled to capture investor interest on Thursday and brokers said a government order to crack down on dissent may have had an impact.
The LIBX bank index fell 1.89 percent to 191.31 and the LISPI fell 0.52 percent to 97.20 while the BLOM fell 0.09 percent to 1111.10.
BSE turnover climbed to 192,037 from 173,813 for a value of $2,488,136 against $2,089,456.

Brokers said the Lebanese cabinet's decision late on Wednesday to order the army and security forces to crack down on the leaders of a civil disobedience campaign may have had an indirect impact on the market.

They also speculated that the latest tensions in southern Lebanon where pro-Iranian Hizbollah guerrillas are fighting to drive Israeli forces from the Jewish state's occupation zone may have had an effect.
Former Hizbollah leader Sheikh Sobhi Tufaili has launched a "hunger revolt" in the form of a civil disobedience campaign to highlight what he says is government neglect of the poor.
"The market is not very bullish. Investors do not seem to be as encouraged as before," said one broker who requested anonymity.
"We think this may be due to the latest political developments. It may have had an indirect impact."
Solidere A and B shares held steady at $13.
Banque Libanaise pour le Commerce dropped to $20.25 from $21.25 and Banque Audi fell to $27.25 from $27.50. Bank of Beirut was flat at $5.75.
There was no trade in the other listed industrial firms -- Eternit, Uniceramic and Ciments Blancs - Beirut editorial (9611) 745307 745308 602057
